Situation1: They share only one open evening before a busy travel week.
Situation2: They remain cheerful and patient while handling an upset customer during a peak holiday rush.
Story: Tonight was supposed to be our night. My boyfriend and I had circled this one evening on our calendars weeks ago, knowing it was the only time we’d have together before I left for a week-long work trip. He’d planned dinner, even picked out a movie he knew I’d love. But as I was about to clock out from my shift at the grocery store, my manager asked if I could stay late. The holiday rush had brought in a flood of customers, and one woman at my register was already raising her voice, frustrated about a coupon. I could feel my phone buzzing in my pocket—probably my boyfriend, waiting for me. I forced a smile, trying to calm the customer, but my mind was racing. I wanted to be the patient, friendly cashier my boss expected, but all I could think about was disappointing the person I loved. The weight of both roles pressed on me, each demanding something I wasn’t sure I could give.
